quotes.quote: Perception is reality. If you are perceived to be something, you might as well be it because that's the truth in people's minds.
There are things known and there are things unknown, and in between are the doors of perception.
One has not only an ability to perceive the world but an ability to alter one's perception of it; more simply, one can change things by the manner in which one looks at them.
If the doors of perception were cleansed everything would appear to man as it is, infinite.
No two people see the external world in exactly the same way. To every separate person a thing is what he thinks it is -- in other words, not a thing, but a think.
We don't see things as they are. We see them as we are.
Perception is merely reality filtered through the prism of your soul.
We can always choose to perceive things differently. You can focus on what's wrong in your life, or you can focus on what's right.
Trust in yourself. Your perceptions are often far more accurate than you are willing to believe.
What you see and hear depends a good deal on where you are standing; it also depends on what sort of person you are.
The eye sees only what the mind is prepared to comprehend.
Our vulgar perception is not concerned with other than vulgar phenomena.
People only see what they are prepared to see.
There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
The auditory perception is not sufficient for our knowledge of the world; it does not have vastness.
Many of the truths we cling to depend greatly on our point of view.
Man's mind, once stretched by a new idea, never regains its original dimensions.
Perception is strong and sight weak. In strategy it is important to see distant things as if they were close and to take a distanced view of close things.
If you can change your perception, you can change your emotion and this can lead to new ideas.
Heightened perception is the goal: becoming more aware of how you see, not just what you see.
Perception is demonstrably an active rather than a passive process; it constructs rather than records 'reality'.
Blessed are they who see beautiful things in humble places where other people see nothing.
Some people see the cup as half empty. Some people see the cup as half full. I see the cup as too large.
A fool sees not the same tree that a wise man sees.
It all depends on how we look at things, and not how they are in themselves.
It is one of the commonest of mistakes to consider that the limit of our power of perception is also the limit of all there is to perceive.
It's not what you look at that matters, it's what you see.
All things are subject to interpretation. Whichever interpretation prevails at a given time is a function of power and not truth.
You will always define events in a manner which will validate your agreement with reality.
It doubles your perception, to write from the point of view of someone you're not.
